boat.name: Minx
boat.full_description:
'Minx' is one of several GRP Morecambe Bay prawners built from a mould taken from the 'Sir William Priestley' the Morecambe Bay Fishermen's Association's private lifeboat which served from 1934 to 1987.

Built by Eric Bergqvist and designed by Crossfield, Peter Tomlinson purchased the hull of 'Minx' in 1990, fitted her out and rigged her over a five year period, launching her in 1996 and sailing in the Bristol Channel area. In 2015 she changed hands and moved to the South West, regularly taking part in events including Falmouth and Plymouth.

'Sir William Priestley' was the Morecambe Fisherman’s private lifeboat built by William Crossfield & Sons in 1934. Lady Priestley donated the money in memory of her husband, a Bradford mill owner, MP and supporter of the RNLI. Sir William had been involved in fundraising for the Spurn Head lifeboat 'City of Bradford II'. Morecambe was popular with holidaymakers from Bradford and was often known as 'Bradford by the Sea'. The naming of the 'Sir William Priestley' was attended by the Lord Mayors of Bradford and Leeds and she was paraded through the streets of Morecambe and Heysham watched by 20,000 people.

Six or more replicas have been made of the 'Sir William Priestley' in glass fibre using a mould taken from the boat in 1979 by Eric Bergqvist, a Cheshire boatbuilder in return for royalties of £25 for every boat built. The 'Sir William Priestley' was retired from service in 1987 and taken to Lancaster Maritime Museum to await restoration.

Alasdair Simpson, Arnside Sailing Club, September 2018
